questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with symptoms of jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. On further investigation, he is diagnosed with a viral hepatitis infection. The attending physician is curious about the nature of the virus responsible for his condition. Which of the following hepatitis viruses is the only one classified as a DNA virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the hepatitis viruses, the only DNA virus is HBV which belongs to the family hepadnaviridae.

The characteristics of various hepatitis viruses are summarised in the table given below.

questions.text: Identify the various components of the Hepatitis B virus genome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The option C correctly matches the various components of the Hepatitis B virus genome.
  • Hepatitis B virus (HBV), a hepadnavirus, is an enveloped DNA virus with a nucleocapsid.
  • Its genome is a small, circular, partially double-stranded DNA but replicates via an RNA intermediate using a reverse transcriptase enzyme as shown below.
  • The HBV virion contains several key components, including a protein kinase and a polymerase enzyme that possesses both reverse transcriptase and RNase H activity. A P protein is also bound to the viral genome.
  • These elements are enclosed within an icosahedral capsid composed of the hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg), which itself is encased in an outer envelope embedded with three glycoprotein forms of the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg).
  • The hepatitis Be antigen (HBeAg), though structurally related to HBcAg, is processed differently by being secreted into the bloodstream, lacking the capacity for self-assembly, and displaying distinct antigenic features.
  • HBsAg, formerly known as the Australia antigen, consists of three glycoproteins: L, M, and S.
  • HBcAg is located within the infected cells or virions and is not detectable by circulating antibodies, allowing anti-HBc to be present throughout and following the infection.
  • HBV may contribute to the development of primary hepatocellular carcinoma (PHC) through chronic liver inflammation, which promotes cycles of tissue damage and regeneration. Additionally, HBV can integrate into the host genome, disrupting chromosomal structure, positioning viral promoters near host growth-regulating genes, and inducing genetic instability.
  • The HBV X gene may further facilitate oncogenesis by activating the expression of host cell proteins, thereby promoting cell proliferation and survival, which can lead to malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old medical student pricks her fingers with a used needle accidentally during a blood draw. It was later found that the needle which she had been injured with had been used to draw samples from an HBV infected patient. She was immediately started on post exposure prophylaxis for HBV. Later, her blood is sent for examination for serological markers for HBV infection. Had she been infected, which of the following antigens would not be seen in her blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among the given options, HBcAg is not seen in the blood as it is located within the infected cells.
  • Hepatitis B virus (HBV), a member of the hepadnavirus family, is an enveloped DNA virus that contains a nucleocapsid.
  • Although it is a DNA virus, HBV uses an RNA intermediate during replication, facilitated by reverse transcriptase.
  • Hepatitis B virus has an icosahedral capsid built from the hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg), which is itself surrounded by an envelope containing three glycoprotein forms of the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg).
  • Particles containing HBsAg are released into the bloodstream of infected individuals and are more numerous than the actual virus particles. (Option B ruled out)
  • Hepatitis Be antigen (HBeAg), which shares most of its sequence with HBcAg, is processed differently: it is secreted into the blood, does not self-assemble like HBcAg, and displays unique antigenic characteristics. (Option A ruled out)
  • HBcAg is confined within infected cells or virions, remaining inaccessible to circulating antibodies, which permits anti-HBc detection both during and after infection. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Lamivudine is a Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) which has proven antiviral activity against HIV and HBV. However, some patients infected with HBV are resistant to Lamivudine. Which mutation confers this property of drug resistance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The YMDD mutation in the Hepatitis B virus DNA polymerase confers drug resistance to the virus against lamivudine.
  • Lamivudine is an oral nucleoside analogue that inhibits reverse transcriptase, blocking viral replication in both HBV and HIV.
  • Approved as the first antiviral for HBV, it was widely used to suppress HBV DNA, improve liver histology, and reduce fibrosis and cirrhosis.
  • Clinical trials showed that a daily dose of 100 mg reduced HBV DNA levels significantly, especially in HBeAg-positive patients.
  • However, long-term use is limited by the development of viral resistance, often due to mutations in the YMDD motif of the HBV DNA polymerase, particularly the M204V/I mutations.
  • Resistance led to reduced virologic and clinical responses, requiring additional antivirals like adefovir or tenofovir.
  • Despite initial benefits, many patients experienced virologic relapse after discontinuing therapy, especially those with HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B or core promoter mutations.

Explanation of other options:

Pre-core mutation (Option B): Precore mutants of HBV result from mutations in the precore region of the C gene, most notably a G-to-A substitution at nucleotide 1896 that introduces a premature stop codon, halting the translation of HBeAg. Another category involves mutations in the core promoter region, which suppress transcription of the HBeAg coding region. These mutations produce a phenotype with detectable HBV DNA but absence of HBeAg, despite the presence of anti-HBe antibodies. Such patients tend to have more severe or advanced liver disease and are often identified later in the disease course.

Escape mutation (Option C): Escape mutants of HBV involve a mutation at position 145 of the HBsAg, replacing glycine with arginine. This structural alteration impairs antibody recognition, leading to loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs. These mutants have been found in individuals who developed HBV infection despite prior immunization or passive immunotherapy, such as liver transplant recipients treated with monoclonal anti-HBs. Although not frequently recognized, their potential to evade immune detection poses challenges for both vaccination effectiveness and accurate serologic diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with chronic Hepatitis B infection is attending her antenatal check-up. The doctor informs her that Hepatitis B can be transmitted to the baby during delivery. What is the most common mode of vertical transmission of HBV?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatitis B is primarily transmitted via percutaneous exposure, although this route alone does not account for all cases. Many individuals with acute HBV lack any identifiable exposure history.
  • Besides percutaneous transmission, nonpercutaneous routes, especially sexual contact and perinatal transmission also play a significant role.
  • Although the exact mechanism of perinatal HBV transmission is not clearly defined, evidence indicates that the majority of cases occur around the time of birth rather than during pregnancy, and breastfeeding does not contribute to transmission and is therefore not contraindicated. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • The risk of transmission is strongly linked to maternal HBeAg positivity and high viral load. Around 90% of HBeAg-positive mothers pass the infection to their infants, compared to only 10-15% of those who are anti-HBe-positive.
  • While the newborn typically shows no symptoms during acute infection, there is a high probability that the child will develop chronic hepatitis B.
  • HBsAg has been found in numerous body fluids, with semen and saliva being particularly infectious.
  • Although HBV was once associated with transfusions, current screening techniques have reduced this transmission route to extremely low levels.

questions.text: What will be the serological profile of a patient infected with acute HBV during its maximum infectivity period?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The serological profile of a patient infected with acute HBV during its maximum infectivity period will be HBsAg +ve and HBeAg +ve.

Explanation of other options:

Anti HBsAg +ve and Anti HBeAg +ve (Option A): Suggestive of acute or chronic hepatitis with low infectivity or precore mutant HBV.

Only anti-HBsAg +ve (Option B): Suggestive of post-vaccination immunity, false positive anti-HBs or resolved hepatitis B.

HBsAg -ve and IgM anti-HBc +ve (Option D): Seen in window period of HBV infection.

choices.text: Immune complex deposition due to chronic hepatitis B infection
Direct viral invasion of vascular endothelium
Type I hypersensitivity to hepatitis B surface antigen

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, fever, and abdominal pain. Laboratory tests reveal elevated ESR and renal dysfunction. Hepatitis B surface antigen is positive. A biopsy of a medium-sized muscular artery shows transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis. Which of the following best explains the underlying association in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polyarteritis nodosa associated with HBV arises due to immune complex deposition involving hepatitis B antigens.
  • Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN) is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- and medium-sized muscular arteries, especially those supplying the kidneys and viscera, while sparing pulmonary vessels.
  • It is not associated with ANCA, but up to one-third of patients have chronic hepatitis B, which leads to deposition of HBsAg-HBsAb immune complexes in vessels. The condition’s clinical effects arise from ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues. (Option C ruled out)
  • Morphologically, PAN is marked by segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation in affected arteries, often leading to thrombosis and aneurysm formation.
  • Commonly affected organs include the kidneys, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. Lesions typically involve branch points and may cause ischemic injury downstream.
  • The acute phase features mixed inflammatory infiltrates and fibrinoid necrosis, while chronic stages show fibrous thickening. Multiple stages of lesion development may coexist in a single vessel.
  • Clinically, PAN often presents in young adults with a remitting and episodic course. Symptoms vary widely due to the dispersed vascular involvement and include rapidly progressing hypertension (from renal artery disease), abdominal pain, GI bleeding, myalgias, and motor neuropathy.
  • Renal disease is a major contributor to mortality. If untreated, PAN is usually fatal, but immunosuppressive therapy can lead to remission or cure in 90% of cases.

Explanation of other options:

Direct viral invasion of vascular endothelium (Option B): Incorrect since polyarteritis nodosa is immune-complex mediated.

Type I hypersensitivity to hepatitis B surface antigen (Option D): Polyarteritis nodosa involves type III hypersensitivity (immune complex-mediated)

questions.text: A 35-year-old healthcare worker presents for routine screening for Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. The laboratory tests show the presence of a specific marker in his blood that indicates active HBV infection. Which of the following is used as an epidemiological marker of HBV infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HBsAg(Hepatitis B surface antigen) is the primary epidemiological marker used for Hepatitis B virus.
  • HBsAgis a protein found on the surface of the Hepatitis B virus. Its presence in the blood indicates active infection with HBV. If a person tests positive for HBsAg, they are either actively infected or may be a carrier of the virus.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-HBsAg (Option B): This is the antibody against the Hepatitis B surface antigen. The presence of anti-HBs indicates immunity to the virus, either from previous infection (recovery) or vaccination. It is not used as an epidemiological marker of infection, but rather as an indicator of immunity.

HBV DNA titre (Option C): The presence of HBV DNA in the blood reflects the amount of viral replication and is used for assessing the degree of infection and monitoring treatment in chronic HBV infection. However, it is not an epidemiological marker for the presence of infection itself. HBsAg is more commonly used for initial screening.

ALT, AST values (Option D): These are liver enzyme levels and are used to assess liver damage or inflammation, not directly to diagnose or mark the presence of HBV infection. Elevated ALT and AST can be seen in HBV infection, but they are not specific epidemiological markers for the virus.

questions.text: A final-year medical student was bitten by his pet dog. He received rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) and the rabies vaccine as part of post-exposure prophylaxis. The attending medical officer asked the student to name other vaccines that can be administered with immunoglobulin for post-exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following vaccines can be taken with immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In addition to rabies, both HBV and tetanus vaccine and immunoglobulin can be administered at the same time.
  • For individuals without prior hepatitis B vaccination who are exposed to HBV, it is advised to administer both hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) for immediate high-level anti-HBs protection and the hepatitis B vaccine to establish long-term immunity and potentially reduce the severity of illness.
  • In newborns of HBsAg-positive mothers, a 0.5 mL intramuscular dose of HBIG should be given in the thigh immediately after birth, along with the first dose of the three-shot hepatitis B vaccine series, started within 12 hours of delivery.
  • In cases of direct percutaneous or mucosal exposure, such as needlestick injuries or contact with infected fluids, a 0.06 mL/kg IM dose of HBIG should be given as soon as possible, followed by the hepatitis B vaccine series initiated within seven days.
  • For sexual exposure to someone with acute hepatitis B, the same HBIG dose (0.06 mL/kg IM) should be administered within 14 days, followed by the full vaccine series. When both HBIG and the vaccine are needed, they can be given simultaneously but at different injection sites.
  • People who experience wounds with a high risk of tetanus should receive immunization if they have not completed their vaccination series, their status is uncertain, or if their last booster was administered more than 10 years ago. Additionally, those with insufficient immunization who suffer wounds that are more than just clean or minor should also receive tetanus immune globulin (TIG) for passive protection.

Explanation of other options:

Varicella (Option C): The three modalities used in varicella prevention are vaccines, immunoglobulin administration, and antivirals in those ineligible for vaccination . Vaccination and immunoglobulin are not administered together.

choices.text: Initiate a full 3-dose HBV vaccination series
Restart the entire series of 5 doses

questions.text: A 30-year-old healthcare worker sustains a needlestick injury from a patient who is HBV-positive. The healthcare worker has been fully vaccinated against HBV; however, her anti-HBs titre are <10 mIU/mL, indicating non-protective levels. She receives Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 2 hours of the injury. What should be the next step in managing her vaccination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As the healthcare worker has been vaccinated against HBV but has anti-HBs levels below 10 mIU/mL, indicating inadequate protection, the appropriate course is to initiate a full 3-dose HBV vaccination series.
  • The 5-dose HBV vaccine is not in practice (Option C ruled out)

Post exposure prophylaxis fo HBV:

HCW: health-care worker

questions.text: A third-year MBBS student, who has just started clinical postings, is eager to take a blood sample from a patient. The nurse, however, asks the student about their Hepatitis B vaccination status as a precautionary measure before proceeding. What is the recommended vaccination schedule for Hepatitis B in adults?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The routine vaccination regimen involves administering three intramuscular injections at intervals of 0, 1, and 6 months.
  • Hepatitis B preexposure prophylaxis is recommended for individuals with frequent exposure risk, such as healthcare workers, hemodialysis staff and patients, incarcerated individuals, injection drug users, and people with multiple or high-risk sexual contacts.
  • It also includes those living in or traveling to endemic areas, unvaccinated children under 18, individuals with chronic liver or renal disease, HIV infection, and specific ethnic or immigrant populations from areas with high HBV prevalence.
  • The standard vaccination schedule consists of three intramuscular doses at 0, 1, and 6 months. (Options B, C and D ruled out)
  • The two original recombinant hepatitis B vaccines with aluminum adjuvant are considered equivalent. One contains 10 μg of HBsAg (Recombivax-HB) and the other 20 μg (Engerix-B), though the recommended dosing varies between them.
  • Combination vaccines that include hepatitis B with other childhood immunizations are also available.

questions.text: HDV requires HBsAg from HBV to infect humans. Which of the following infections does the following serological profile indicate? IgG anti-HBc + mixture of IgM and IgG anti-HDV
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of anti-HDV antibodies along with IgG anti-HBc suggests superinfection of HDV on HBV.
  • HDV infection can be identified either by detecting HDV antigen in liver tissue or, more commonly, through anti-HDV seroconversion, indicated by a rising titer or new appearance of anti-HDV antibodies.
  • Circulating HDV antigen is a marker of acute infection but is usually detectable for only a short time, if at all.
  • Because anti-HDV often disappears after HBsAg clears, confirming a past, self-limited co-infection with HBV and HDV can be challenging. Additionally, the appearance of anti-HDV antibodies may be delayed by 30-40 days, complicating early diagnosis.
  • When a patient has acute hepatitis along with serum HBsAg and anti-HDV, determining the class of anti-HBc antibodies helps clarify the timing and relationship of the infections.
  • The presence of IgM anti-HBc suggests a recent HBV infection, while its absence (and presence of IgG anti-HBc) indicates a past infection.
  • Thus, in co-infection with acute HBV and HDV, IgM anti-HBc is present, while in HDV superinfection on chronic HBV, anti-HBc is of the IgG type.

Explanation of other options:

Co-infection of HDV and HBV (Option B): Occurs when a person is simultaneously infected with HBV (IgM anti-HBc positive) and HDV. In this case, the patient has IgG anti-HBc (chronic HBV), not IgM, ruling out co-infection.

HBV infection alone (Option C): The presence of anti-HDV antibodies rules out this options.

Recovery from hepatitis B (Option D): The presence of anti-HDV antibodies suggests a Hepatitis D virus infection.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male doctor presents after a needlestick exposure. Additional tests are ordered based on patient request. The results are as follows:
HIV Ag/Ab: Negative/Negative
HBsAg: Negative
HBsAb: Positive
Hepatitis C antibody: Negative
HBc IgM: Negative
HBc IgG: Positive
What is the most likely explanation of the results above?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The presence of anti-HBs along with IgG anti-HBc suggests recovery phase following an HBV infection.

The temporal pattern of HBV serology is as shown below.

Explanation of other options:

Acute infection (Option A): Acute infection is characterised by the presence of HBsAg along with IgM anti-HBc.

Chronic infection (Option B): Chronic infection is identified by the presence of HBsAg along with IgG anti-HBc.

Immunity after vaccination (Option D): The presence of Anti-HBs alone suggests immunity after vaccination.

choices.text: Single-stranded positive-sense non-enveloped linear RNA virus
Single-stranded positive-sense enveloped linear RNA virus

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with 2 weeks of nausea, diarrhea & vague abdominal pain after eating at a roadside stall a few days ago. He also has loss of appetite and developed a fever of 102 °F. His labs have elevated transaminases, with an ALT of 10,000 U/L and AST of 8,000 U/L. Which of the following best describes the causative agent of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette of gastrointestinal symptoms along with elevated transaminases after eating roadside food is suggestive of Hepatitis A virus infection caused by a single-stranded positive sense non-enveloped RNA virus.
  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) belongs to the Picornaviridae family with a linear single-stranded positive sense RNA genome. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • HAV is transmitted almost entirely via the fecal-oral route. The infection is associated with poor sanitation and overcrowding, spreading through direct person-to-person contact or ingestion of contaminated food and water.
  • Outbreaks have been linked to shellfish, frozen fruits, and imported produce. Transmission within households and institutions is common, with a seasonal tendency to occur in autumn.
  • Hepatitis A typically has an abrupt onset, often with fever above 38°C. It is more symptomatic in adults than in children, with the illness tending to be more severe as the incidence of subclinical childhood infection declines.
  • The disease rarely leads to complications, and chronic infection does not occur. The incubation period ranges from 10 to 50 days, averaging 25-30 days.
  • The virus is most commonly found in the stool from about 2 weeks before to 2 weeks after jaundice onset. Mortality in icteric cases remains under 0.5%. Homologous immunity follows infection and is likely lifelong.
  • Diagnosis can be supported by biochemical tests such as ALT, AST, and bilirubin. HAV particles can be visualized in stool using immune electron microscopy. The virus is detectable in stool, liver, bile, and blood using PCR or immunoassays, starting around 2 weeks before and up to 2 weeks after the onset of jaundice.
  • Serological testing reveals that IgM anti-HAV peaks around two weeks after enzyme elevation and becomes undetectable within 3-6 months, while IgG anti-HAV appears soon after symptom onset and persists for life.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 at 32-weeks gestation presents with severe abdominal pain, fatigue, and nausea. Physical examination shows jaundice and RUQ tenderness. Infection with which of the following organisms has the highest mortality rate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus which belongs to the Hepeviridae family. The virus lacks an envelope and has a naked capsid.
  • HEV is transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route, most often via contaminated water.
  • HEV infection typically results in an acute, self-limiting hepatitis with symptoms that mirror those of hepatitis A, though they may have a delayed onset. Unlike hepatitis A, HEV does not cause chronic infection.
  • The disease severity is higher in certain groups, especially in pregnant women, where fulminant hepatitis may lead to a mortality rate of up to 20% while in the general population, the mortality rate is about 1-2%.
  • On the other hand, the main concern with Hepatitis B, C, and D viruses is perinatal transmission. While hepatitis A generally does not significantly affect pregnancy outcomes in low-resource settings, both maternal and perinatal mortality are notably higher. Hepatitis A is not teratogenic, poses minimal fetal transmission risk, though preterm birth and neonatal cholestasis have been noted. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to your office with decreased appetite, malaise, and fever. Serologic tests reveal positive anti-HBsAg and anti-HAV IgM antibodies. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Positive anti-HBsAg and ant-HAV IgM antibodies is suggestive of acute hepatitis A infection in a patient vaccinated against HBV and since HAV spreads through fecal-oral route, shellfish consumption is the likely etiology.
  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is classified within the Picornaviridae family and possesses a linear, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome.
  • Its transmission occurs almost exclusively through the fecal-oral route, often associated with inadequate hygiene and crowded conditions. Spread typically happens via direct contact or through consumption of contaminated water and food, with outbreaks linked to shellfish, frozen berries, and imported vegetables
  • Household and institutional transmission is frequent, and cases tend to rise during autumn.
  • Clinically, hepatitis A presents suddenly and frequently includes fever exceeding 38°C. Adults experience more pronounced symptoms compared to children, particularly in populations where subclinical childhood infection is less common.
  • The disease generally resolves without complications and does not become chronic. The incubation period spans from 10 to 50 days, with an average of 25 to 30 days.
  • Laboratory diagnosis involves liver function tests such as ALT, AST, and bilirubin levels. HAV particles can be identified in fecal samples via immune electron microscopy, and the virus may be detected in stool, liver, bile, and blood using PCR or immunological methods from two weeks prior to jaundice until two weeks after.
  • Serological testing shows that anti-HAV IgM peaks roughly two weeks after enzyme elevation and typically declines within 3 to 6 months. Anti-HAV IgG appears shortly after disease onset and remains detectable for life.

Explanation of other options:

Needlestick (Option A): HBV, HCV, and HDV spread through percutaneous routes.

Unprotected sexual intercourse (Option B): HBV, HCV, and HDV can be transmitted through unprotected sexual intercourse.

Paracetamol overdose (Option D): Acetaminophen induces dose-dependent centrilobular liver necrosis, either following a single large ingestion in cases of intentional self-harm or gradually through unintentional overdose. The serological findings in this patient rules out this option.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of fatigue and joint and muscle pain. He has a history of intravenous drug use. Lab panel is as below:
Hepatitis A IgM: Negative
Hepatitis A IgG: Negative
Hepatitis B surface antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B E antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B core antigen: Negative
Hepatitis B surface IgG: Positive
Hepatitis B E IgG: Negative
Hepatitis B core IgG: Negative
Hepatitis C IgG: Positive
HCV RNA: 100,000,000 IU/ml
This patient should be started on which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's serological profile is consistent with a diagnosis of chronic HCV infection with immunity against HBV infection and HCV can be treated with sofosbuvir/ledipasvir.
  • Among HBV serological markers, the patient has only anti-HbsAg IgG +ve with indicates immunity against HBV infection. Snce the Hepatitis C IgG is +ve along with HCV RNA of 100,000,000 IU/ml it suggests chronic hepatitis C infection.
  • Sofosbuvir/ledipasvir is a fixed-dose combination used to treat HCV genotypes 1, 4, and 6, with a standard duration of 12 weeks.
  • It requires no dose modification in decompensated cirrhosis (Child–Pugh B or C). Food enhances its absorption, while antacids and PPIs may reduce it.
  • As a P-glycoprotein inhibitor, ledipasvir may elevate tenofovir levels, necessitating renal monitoring when both are used.
  • Clinical trials report good tolerability with few side effects, such as fatigue and headache, similar to placebo.

Explanation of other options:

Entacavir (Option A): Entecavir is approved by the FDA for managing chronic hepatitis B in both adults and children aged 2 years and older who show signs of active viral replication along with either sustained elevated liver enzymes or liver biopsy evidence of active disease.

Tenofovir (Option B): Approved for the treatment of HIV-1 and HBV.

Lamivudine (Option D): Lamivudine is a nucleoside analogue that targets both HIV reverse transcriptase and hepatitis B virus DNA polymerase.

choices.text: Give Hep B immunoglobulins to newborn
Treatment with ribavirin and interferon combination

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant female comes to Medicine OPD. Her serology testing shows that anti-HBs antibody and hepatitis C IgG antibody are both positive. HBeAg, HbsAg, and hepatitis A antibody are negative. Polymerase chain reaction of hepatitis C RNA is positive for genotype 1. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patients serological profile is consistent with a diagnosis of chronic hepatitis C infection with immunity against HBV infection with no active hepatitis A infection which makes Hepatitis A vaccination the most appropriate recommendation at this time.
  • Hepatitis A is an RNA picornavirus transmitted via the fecal-oral route, commonly through contaminated food or water.
  • Vaccination, especially during childhood, is over 90% effective and is advised for high-risk adults, including pregnant women, individuals with chronic liver disease, HIV, homelessness, or substance use, and those working or traveling in high-risk settings.
  • Unvaccinated pregnant women with recent exposure should receive passive immunization with immune globulin and begin the vaccine series simultaneously.
  • In pregnancy, hepatitis A generally leads to mild illness and does not significantly affect outcomes in developed countries. However, in resource-limited settings, maternal and perinatal mortality may be higher.
  • Although HAV is not teratogenic and fetal transmission is minimal, risks such as preterm birth and neonatal cholestasis have been reported.

Explanation of other options:

Give Hep B immunoglobulins to newborn (Option A): Since the patient has anti-HBs Ag +ve with HBsAh -ve, it indicates immunity against hepatitis B infection which rules out the possibility of perinatal transmission of HBV.

Liver biopsy (Option C): Since currently no medical therapy is approved for use in hepatitis C in pregnancy, a liver biopsy is not warranted.

Treatment with ribavirin and interferon combination(Option D): Ribavirin, a nucleoside analogue, is part of hepatitis C treatment and is used in combination with pegylated interferon. This is not considered inferior to directly acting antiviral treatments for Hepatitis iC infection. Moreover, ribavarin has teratogenic effects in various animal species even at low doses and hence is not used in pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient comes with a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash, fatigue, and hematuria. Physical examination shows multiple erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. Serum creatinine is elevated and urinalysis shows red blood cell casts and protein. Serum complement levels are decreased. Renal biopsy shows subendothelial immune complex deposits with granular immunofluorescence and tram-track basement membrane splitting. Which of the following will be most likely seen on lab investigations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of hematuria, cutaneous vasculitis with subendothelial immune complex deposits in the kidney is suggestive of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis which is associated with hepatitis C and hence anti-hepatitis C antibodies will be seen on lab investigations.
  • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is a systemic condition resulting from the presence of cryoglobulins (cold-precipitable monoclonal or polyclonal immunoglobulins) that deposit in small- to medium-sized blood vessels.
  • It typically presents with features such as palpable purpura, joint pains, fatigue, nerve involvement, and kidney inflammation.
  • Though most frequently associated with hepatitis C, it can also occur with other conditions like multiple myeloma, lymphoproliferative disorders, connective tissue diseases, infections, liver disease, or without a known cause.
  • An estimated 5% of chronic hepatitis C patients develop this vasculitis. Skin biopsy shows inflammation with vessel wall damage, immune complex deposition, and complement activation.
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis accounts for the majority of renal involvement. The connection to hepatitis C is supported by findings such as detectable viral RNA, antibodies in cryoprecipitates, viral antigens in skin lesions, and response to antiviral therapy.
  • The underlying mechanism involves immune complexes such as hepatitis C antigens, specific antibodies, and rheumatoid factor, depositing in vessels, initiating inflammation.
  • Cryoprecipitates in the blood are diagnostic, and rheumatoid factor is commonly found. Most patients also show low complement levels, elevated inflammatory markers, and anemia. All patients with suspected disease should be evaluated for hepatitis C antibodies and RNA.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-GBM antibodies (Option A): It is suggestive of Goodpastures syndrome will shows linear immunofluorescence staining and presents with pulmonary and renal manifestations.

c-ANCA positivity (Option B): Points to a diagnosis of Wegener’s granulomatosis which leads to pauci-immune rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Anti-centromere antibodies (Option D): Seen in CREST syndrome characterised by Raynaud’s phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, calcinosis, and telangiectasia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized malaise, yellowish discoloration of the eyes, and pruritus on the back of his hands that worsens when exposed to sunlight for the past several months. He has not seen a physician in 15 years. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild jaundice. There is a purpuric rash on the dorsum of both hands. He is negative for HBsAg. The causal pathogen of this patient's underlying condition was most likely acquired in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario with jaundice, pruritus and purpuric rash is suggestive of hepatitis C infection which is most likely accquired through needlestick injury.
  • Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus from the Flaviviridae
  • Multiple genotypes and subtypes exist due to genetic variability, although this variability does not impact disease severity but does influence treatment response.
  • Most new infections are asymptomatic, but 70-90% progress to chronic hepatitis, with a subset advancing to cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Transmission primarily occurs through parenteral routes like transfusions or injection drug use, though sexual and perinatal spread are less common.
  • Screening of blood donors and the advent of direct-acting antivirals have significantly reduced transfusion-related transmission and disease burden.
  • Routine screening, especially in high-risk populations including pregnant women, is now recommended.
  • Hepatitis C virus triggers both innate and adaptive immune responses, particularly through T cells producing antiviral cytokines. Despite this, HCV is adept at evading immune detection, leading to chronic infection.
  • Some patients may also exhibit cross-reactivity between HCV antigens and autoantigens, such as cytochrome P450 2D6, which has been associated with autoimmune hepatitis featuring anti-LKM antibodies.
  • A notable extrahepatic manifestation of chronic hepatitis C is essential mixed cryoglobulinemia (EMC), which is characterized by arthritis, palpable purpura from cutaneous vasculitis, and occasionally glomerulonephritis.
  • This condition is marked serologically by circulating immune complexes composed of multiple immunoglobulin classes containing HCV RNA.
  • Following acute hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, up to 85-90% of individuals develop chronic infection. Many of those with chronic hepatitis C remain asymptomatic, however, cirrhosis may eventually develop in about 20% of cases over 10 to 20 years.
  • Disease progression is more likely with older age at infection, long-standing infection, immune suppression, excessive alcohol intake, fatty liver, other hepatitis viruses, or HIV co-infection. In fact, severe and fast-progressing hepatitis B or C is increasingly recognized in those with HIV.
  • For those with chronic hepatitis C, liver cancer risk is also elevated but is largely confined to patients with cirrhosis, usually developing after three decades of disease. In such cirrhotic HCV patients, the annual chance of hepatocellular cancer ranges from approximately 1% to 4%.

Explanation of other options:

Eating contaminated raw shellfish (Option A): Hepatitis A and E viruses are acquired by the fecal-oral route.

Droplet infection (Option C): Hepatitis viruses are not spread through droplets.

Bathing in freshwater (Option D): Hepatitis E is linked with water-borne outbreaks

choices.text: Ground glass hepatocytes and periportal inflammation

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of malaise, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain after eating contaminated food. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness. The liver is palpated 1.5 cm below the right costal margin. A biopsy specimen of this patient's liver would most likely show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of gastrointestinal symptoms, jaundice, and hepatomegaly after eating contaminated food is suggestive of acute viral hepatitis in which histopathological examination may reveal confluent necrosis and ballooning degeneration.
  • Acute hepatitis displays variable liver size and may be normal, enlarged due to inflammation, or shrunken in cases leading to acute liver failure and massive necrosis.
  • Histologically, there is a prominent portal and lobular inflammatory infiltrate, mainly composed of lymphocytes, sometimes accompanied by plasma cells and eosinophils.
  • Hepatocellular injury may manifest as necrosis or apoptosis, often accompanied by pigmented macrophages clearing cellular debris.
  • In more severe cases, clusters of dead hepatocytes leading to confluent necrosis is seen and may progress to necrosis of the entire lobule (panlobular/panacinar necrosis) or spread between vascular structures (bridging necrosis).
  • Ballooning degeneration, cholestasis, apoptotic bodies, and bridging necrosis are other features that can be seen in acute hepatitis.

Explanation of other options:

Florid duct lesion (Option A): Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune condition marked by inflammatory damage to the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts. Morphologically it is marked by lymphocytic infiltration and epithelial damage of small interlobular bile ducts, often with granulomatous destruction, known as florid duct lesions.

Ground glass hepatocytes and periportal inflammation (Option B): Chronic hepatitis is defined histologically by a portal-based lymphocytic or lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate with associated fibrosis, which may extend into surrounding hepatocytes as interface activity. As the disease progresses, fibrosis develops from portal and periportal regions, advancing to bridging fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. Distinctive features include "ground-glass" hepatocytes in hepatitis B due to HBsAg accumulation.

Necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrate and Mallory bodies (Option C): Chronic hepatitis C commonly displays noticeable clusters of lymphoid cells or well-developed lymphoid follicles within the portal tracts.

choices.text: Anti-LKM 3 antibody is associated with hepatitis B infection
Anti-LKM 1 antibody is associated with hepatitis C infection
IgM anti HAV antibody appear during the late incubation period in hepatitis A infection
Enterically transmitted non-A and non-B hepatitis is caused by hepatitis E

questions.text: Identify the false statement
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anti-LKM 3 antibody is associated with hepatitis D infection.
  • Anti-LKM (liver kidney microsomal) antibodies are seen in various conditions as given in the table below.

Explanation of other options:

IgM anti HAV antibody appear during the late incubation period (Option C): During acute hepatitis A, IgM-class anti-HAV antibodies appear early when liver enzymes are elevated and the virus is shed in stool and usually last for up to 3 months. IgG-class anti-HAV antibodies emerge later during recovery and persist for life, providing lasting immunity. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting IgM anti-HAV during the acute phase.

Enterically transmitted non-A and non-B hepatitis is caused by hepatitis E (Option D): Hepatitis E is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route and was previously labeled epidemic or enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis.
